description.text:
Holder for three 5mm LEDs designed for Wade's extruder and others with 5cm screw spacing.
Better staring at the object you are printing :)
Slice it, print it, fit with three LEDs connected in parallel, add resistor (220 ohm, 2W for 30mA LEDs and 12V power), mount under extruder and stare :)

comments.text: If you put the LEDs in series instead of parallel, the required resistor would be 60 ohms and only 1/4 watt, which should be much easier to find and will be cheaper.  Also then the total draw on the power supply is only 20ma rather than 60ma.

description.text:
This is another lasercut - frame printer based on Mendel Prusa i3 and Graber.
Increased frame gives greater print area (200x200x350mm)
You can use any of the carriage for Prusa i3
(I use Rasus carriages http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:174561)
Use 6mm studs and 8mm shafts
Frame is held together with screws m3 20mm
As there are holes for the mounting Arduino Mega (RAMPS)
Use "Another 6" for 6-6.5mm materials, and "Another 7" for 6.5-7mm materials.
NEW: x-carriage to MK7 extruder

just assemble as a constructor and pull with screws
use 8mm rod 2x 500mm, 2x 400mm, 2x 350mm and m6 2x 500mm

Printer Brand:

Formlabs

Printer:

Formlabs Form 2

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.05 mm

Infill:

Manual internal supports

Notes:

Internal supports added by hand in preform. Clear resin V2 was used.

Post processing.

Post processing by IPO bag inside ultrasonic bath for 20 minutes. Then home made UV box for 4 hours using 550nm led strip.

Polished by buffing by green buff, and then gloss acyrlic polish The threads are greased by Shimano machine oil.

Fusion 360

I used a 40 mm cylinder and holed/modeled a M30/3.5 thread inside. I also designed a matching threaded cap. I followed the dimensions in Wikipedia to design a slit that can fit a 2 euro coin

Meshmixer

I imported and hollowed the model. I scaled it to be able to accommodate the cap I designed in Fusion360. I imported the parts from Fusion360 as custom parts, and boolean substracted/ merged them with the model.

Preform

I used a vertical placement with hole facing away from the build platform. I placed the internal supports manually.

description.text:
Needed a way to securely hold a Samsung Galaxy Tab S 8.4 in a keyboard case that was meant for a larger tablet.

This design allows the top clips to flex backwards in order to easily insert and remove the tablet, and has corners on the bottom to prevent the tablet from slipping out sideways.

All of the buttons, jacks, and speakers are fully accessible.

You should be able to re-scale this design to fit a variety of tablets. You could also add different types of mounting points on the back in order to attach it to whatever you need.

This is a wrist-powered device, so the user needs a wrist to be able to actuate the fingers. Version 3 of the Talon Hand easier to build and more comfortable to wear than the Talon Version 2 and it still offers the superior grip strength and effortless actuation of version 2.7 Thanks go out to the designers of the "Complete Set of Mechanical Anatomically Driven Fingers", Ivan Owen of Mech Madness Designs http://mechmadnessdesigns.com/ ; Richard Van As of Robohand http://robohand.net/ ; Michael Curry, the designer of the Snap-Together Robohand ; and to all the collaborators in the e-NABLE global community. Here's a clip of my son Peregrine putting on his Talon 2.2:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=sxmC1vYa0RM&feature=youtu.be
And here's he is playing at home:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=2L0zBrq43E4&feature=youtu.be
After upgrading to 2.7, and some 2.0mm monofilament cables:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=rtojLN_BHts
For more information or to get involved, visit http://enablingthefuture.org/

For the Talon version 3.X, follow the instructions for the Osprey:
https://docs.google.com/document/d/1xbfhPYKO-4hcpnAmYpvGPY-vzPpO1QTiwvFZkcN3034/edit?usp=sharing Obviously, the structure of the Talon is a bit different. Here is a bill of materials: The main difference is that you need a thin piece of leather for the "upper" of the Talon, whereas the dome-shaped palm of the Osprey takes foam. You may choose to apply orthopedic foam to the underside of the Talon's cable guide to protect the user during heavy gripping.

comments.text: I'm having difficulty determining how many screws and lines I need to purchase if I were to print at a 100% scale. Also which size fingers should I print for a 100% scaled print.
comments.author: 17berhey

comments.text:
Good question. You will need 10 x 3/16" #6-32 set screws, 4 x 3/4" #4 pan head sheet metal screws, 16 x 1/2" 1/2" #4 truss head sheet metal screws, 2 x 7/16" #8-32 flat socket head screws, nylon hex jamb nuts or nylon insert lock nuts and 2 #8 flat washers, everything stainless steel. 1.4mm/ ~.05" nylon monofilament for the cables. For the leather bracer and upper, 5oz vegetable tanned leather, and 7oz veg tan leather for the palm. 3/4" nylon webbing for the straps. I think that's about it.
The hardware listed in this response is for a 100% build. Larger builds will need larger hardware.
comments.author: 17berhey

comments.text: Sorry for bothering you, but just to clarify this hardware list is when using the snap pins design correct?
comments.author: profbink

comments.text: That's correct. One set of fingers uses Chicago screws. For 100%, you would need Chicago screws with a 1/8" post and are 1/2" long. If you use Chicago screws, use some kind of thread lock so one side doesn't come loose and get lost. I do recommend the snap pin fingers, as they are very strong and functional, and the pins do a better job of staying in place.
comments.author: 17berhey

comments.text: Where do you suggest purchasing the screws?
comments.author: profbink

comments.text:
I get all my screws from Albany County Fasteners in New Jersey.
If you're asking about Chicago screws, I have found some in aluminum at Lowe's, but those are too big for a 100% print. You can look around on eBay for Chicago screws, but like I said, I highly recommend the snap pin version of the fingers. I don't build with Chicago screws any more, and my son is a heavy duty user of the Talon Hand and the Osprey Hand.
comments.author: 17berhey

comments.text: Fyi, I have discontinued the Chicago screw option. The snap pins work very well, and they scale with the rest of the components. Also, unless you use thread lock, the Chicago screws fall out.
comments.author: profbink

comments.text: does anyone know the difference between the cable anchor and the cable tensioner? in the tutorial videos he uses the tensioner, but I was wondering if they were used for the same purpose?
comments.author: biotech123

comments.text:
Sure. The tensioner is probably the best solution if you're using a braided line, like dyneema, and elastics. You can adjust the tension via little screws in the back of the tensioner block.
The cable anchor is the best option if you're using nylon monofilament.
In the photos the black Talon uses the cable anchor. The blue Talon uses the tensioner. And in the tutorial video, Ivan uses the tensioner.
I would strongly recommend the use of heavy gauge nylon monofilament, since you don't have to use elastics. So the cable anchor is preferable. Check out the Osprey Hand here on Thingiverse, which should give you some ideas.
comments.author: biotech123

comments.text: In the most recent version, I have discontinued the tensioner. Heavy gauge nylon monofilament works much better for cabling anyway, since it doesn't require elastics.

comments.text:
Here is probably the best way to determine the print scale for a device. Or I should say, this is how I do it, and I've had pretty good success so far: You will need an image from DIRECTLY ABOVE the client's affected limb laid flat on the table, with a ruler next to that limb. Best if the camera can also be at least 4 feet away from the table, to reduce distortion. If you can get over two meters away, that's even better. Feel free to use zoom and high resolution so that the markings on the ruler are easy to read. Then follow the video tutorial.
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=aWRIi4bRGHs
You will want this file to get started, unless you're already familiar with Blender: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:564844

comments.author: Btown

comments.text:
Barrett! This is wonderful!!
Thank you for making a Solidworks version. My feeling is the more people who have access to the designs, the better. I'd be happy to work with you, but I'm totally swamped at the moment, between making a deadline on the collaborative E-Nable Hand 2.0, projected for release at the end of September, and the beginning of the school year at the high school where I teach.
If you can't use a program that puts grid lines on .stl imports (like Blender) I'd suggest printing at a giant scale, like 200% and cutting measurements in half. That will greatly reduce the margin of error caused by differing levels of extrusion by different printers. Navigating around an object in Blender is pretty easy. Select metric, hit numpad 5 for ortho view, and use numpad 1,3,and 7 for front, side and top views, respectively. MMB spins the view and shift-mmb pans. Mouse wheel zooms. Z toggles surface
Please let me know if you have specific questions. When you design, moving surfaces should have a gap of .5mm, so they slide freely.
Thank you very much!
comments.author: Btown

title: Beltless motorized camera slider
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This slider is designed to have all the control electronics in the carriage. This allows you to make it as long as you want simply by stretching the tracks. It can be controlled via bluetooth from a smartphone or can be programmed to follow a certain movement. It also has ribaltabile stands, so if you mount it on a tripod, the stands are hidden.
https://youtu.be/PIq2OaEJkaU

To build it, you will need extra material:
-2 ⌀8mm steel bars (as long as you want)
-1 15x15mm aluminium square bar (long as the steel ones)
-8 M3 15mm screws
-8 M3 self-blocking nuts
-6 M4 20mm screws
-2 M4 self-blocking nuts
-4 M4 nuts
-4 ⌀8mm linear bearings
-3 bearings
-1 28byj-48 stepper motor
-1 arduino nano
-1 HC-06 bluetooth module
-1 Lebez 359-B
-1 7.4V 1200mAh battery
-4 vaporizer rubber bands

  • ⌀12x40mm spring
  • some wires

author: ssaucier

description.text:
This Thing provides an easy way to hang up a calendar without drilling or driving any nails or screws into your walls or doors. It's designed to fit a typical 3M Command Strip and still allow access to the release tab. The post should fit most calendars (without stretching or tearing the hole) and should be long enough for a typical 14 month calendar to be flipped all the way through.

Higher extruder temperatures are your friend for best layer adhesion, but you may have to decrease that to avoid a misshapen post. This Thing takes minutes to print so it isn't any big deal to experiment a few times to find how it prints best on your printer. I found it best to print it on its back with no raft, that way you end up with a nice smooth surface to stick your Command Strip to.

I've had it up for a month now with no issues! The calendar shown is the 2017 Snow Leopard Trust calendar, which has very thick pages and I was still able to flip them all up onto the post.

Monoprice Maker Select V2

--Finished Pictures Coming Soon--
This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/hgmbj01j6yb

As you can see from the pictures this is just a standard Mazda badge thats been chopped and adapted to resemble the Batman emblem. The CAD picture was just a screenshot of what it looks like so far with the other picture being on the one I currently have on my car. The one on my car is a OEM part that I cut and sanded down and then painted which led me to the idea of making a keychain of it. Currently im scaling and printing different sized ones to see what size will work and not get stuck in your pocket every time you want your keys. And there are a few edges that I need to change but nothing that would stop you printing it yourself.  
Update. The new picture added is of the first test print. A new revision of this part will be added soon hopefully making it a little bit more durable. 
Update - Car emblem version uploaded.

Currently im using white PLA with 0.1mm layer size with 0.3 nozzle with no infill. Test prints have been fine so far but if you fancy painting it then I would sand it down bit to have a better surface finish.

Cleaning the channel

immediately after the print, I inject IPO to the channel using an injector. After 20 minutes of ultrasonic bath embedded IPO pouch treatment, I use a handheld air pump to clear the channel.

UV post cure,

4 hours inside a home-made UV tank using 550nm led strips

Polishing

I first use 900 and 1200 grit wet sandpaper to get rid of the support marks. Then I use green buff to buff the surface. Then I apply several layers of acyrlic gloss polish. I finish with two layers of gloss varnish spray for hard surface finish.

print_settings.Notes:: My first print of the original thing was at 100% infill.  Man it is solid and will more than meet stresses of my iOptron iEQ45Pro mount, so I don't believe 100% infill would be necessary for even the heaviest applications.  Since its PLA, I do recommend at least a 50% infill, as you don't want ANY flexing in a telescope mount, especially astrophotography.

description.text:

This remix measures about 90mm in diameter and just over an inch thick. I will be using aluminum U channel and clamps to create the entire spreader. I'll post a pic when its done.

I printed in the original thing after scaling it to 80mm in diameter and it will work, but again, I wanted that central mounting hole without drilling and compromising the PLA.

As the title suggest this thing is a fully assembled mars curiosity rover wheel. Obviously not everyone has one of these laying about to take measurements from so ive modeled it from pictures and data of website like wiki. I know that the wheel diameter is 500mm so ive just scaled everything from that. Currently im still playing with the print orientation, support material and the limits and fits with the bolts so that they are just push fit with minimal assembly. If you want to go ahead and print some of the individual parts yourself then there shouldn't be a problem but don't expect to print all the parts and have an easy assembly as they are a work in progress. Follow me on twitter at https://twitter.com/lilykill1 for new models, info and updates If interested, join my group @ http://www.thingiverse.com/groups/design-to-print/topics where I aim to help anybody with anything I can with modeling like this design.
I'm currently using PLA with 0.1 mm layer thickness, 0.3mm nozzle diameter and 0 infill for most parts except for the hub which has a 60-75% infill.

author: enone

description.text: One of the most difficult things for me to do when I was building my first 4x4x4 LED cube was to get the LED cube itself straight and square. The fundamental requirement to do this is to have a perfectly squared and evenly distributed template. I don't know about you, but sucked at it. Not only do you have to get the drill bit perfectly centered in the extact place, but the drill bit cannot shift when drilling and the drill bit has to be perfectly perpendicular to the base. Call me clumsy, hell that's why I bought me a 3D printer :D This template is based on Chr's great Instructable for 4x4x4 and 8x8x8 cubes! Go there and build one! You won't regret it! Also, to do this, I had to jump in and learn OpenSCAD. Amazingly, it took me some 4-6 hours before I could do this model. It's, hands down, the best and easiest 3D modeling software there is! I'm a fan now.

Please open and build ledBaseFineTune.scad first. It will allow you to set your parameters correctly and save time and money printing a template where the LEDs won't fit. I have built the ledBasePlate.stl with parameters to print fine for my 3mm LEDs, in case you can't open the fine tune scad file and you want to jump right in and print the template. Let me know what you think!
(This is my first thing so I hope I didn't screw up anywhere.)

title: Ikea Samla Box Sample Archive / Biobank

description.text:
Recently the need arose for a cost effective sample archive in -80°C freezers. To some extent we have custom tubes, and wanted a stackable storage solution for chest freezers.
Lacking a good commercial solution, I drew up some inserts for Ikea Samla boxes (39x28x14 cm / 11L) to be milled or laser cut (from 40mm XPS foam from the hardware store).

DIN A3 Mylar stencil material was then labeled and cut on a Silhouette Cameo 3 (https://www.amazon.de/gp/product/B008HNQ9A2, penholder with mounted STABILO permanent marker, autoblade on setting 3)

The mylar label allows for the archive position to be entered in the laboratory information system (LIS), so that samples may be retrieved later. Our TA's note the last free box # and position. Samples for the archive are first placed on a separate foam rack (kept near the computer) starting with the last free position. The sample archive positions are then easily entered into the LIS. Later the tubes are transferred to the corresponding box/position near the freezer (preventing unnecessary freeze/thaw cycles). The last free box/position is noted again (on the empty rack that is taken back to the computer worksstation).

title: Phone Stand & Headphone Wrap (Laser Cut and Living Hinges)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
What you see here is the result of a lot of trials and errors. I wanted to make a phone stand using "living hinges." The living hinges allow a single piece of rigid material to bend. The phone stand is cut out of thin 1/8" mfd board using a laser cutter. It is the size of a credit card so it will fit in your wallet. You can also use it as a headphone wrap. The stand has adjustable angles and supports both landscape and portrait orientations. The stand is perfect for video chatting and watching movies. Disclaimer:
While the living hinges give rigid materials flexibility, the hinges will break if over-stressed. The stand's two back support hinges can bend up to about 110 degrees and the front short "phone bracket" can bend 160 degrees. The stand is made using a laser cutter. Laser cutter+ wood=burnt wood. While each stand is given a bubble bath, it will still have a bit of smell to it. The smell is not offensive. Some people
even find the smell pleasant.

Step 1: Get access to laser cutter ( I used 40W laser cutter. Speed=55, power=90. Do some test cuts)
Step 2: Download the the dxf file.
Step 3: (Optional) Be creative! Add some graphics/cutouts to your design.
Step 4: Laser cut it.
Step 4: (Optional) Clean it with a brush using white vinegar and air dry it. FYI: Do not use this design on acrylic. The kerf is different for different materials. You will probably have to modify this design to have it work on acrylic.

This is an extremely basic model of the Nintendo Switch Joycon rails. In Rhino, it's helpful to have this to model around if you're doing a Joycon holster/similar so you can just run a BooleanDifference to get the slots that you need. Available in both .3dm and .stl formats. In the .3dm, everything is saved as separate polysurfaces.

The rail is a smidge deeper than necessary, but as far as friction-fit gear goes, it has worked fine.

This does get the average thickness of the Joycon, but does not have the bulge towards the ZR/ZL buttons, nor the chamfering used since it's just for the rails. If you want to remix it with those on there, let me know because I'd love to use the remix for other controllers.

title: Tomb cover for Gaston de la Foix

description.text:
Tomb cover for Gaston de la Foix (dead 1512) Bambaia, il (Agostino Bustil)(1483 - 1548), 1515-21, Milano, Castello Sforzesco ref 1433. The Royal Cast Collection (Copenhagen, Denmark). Made with Memento Beta (now ReMake) from AutoDesk.
Gaston de Foix, duc de Nemours (10 December 1489 – 11 April 1512), also known as The Thunderbolt of Italy, was a French military commander noted mostly for his brilliant six-month campaign from 1511 to 1512 during the War of the League of Cambrai. Born in Mazères, County of Foix, he was the second child but only son of John of Foix, Viscount of Narbonne and Marie d’Orléans. His older sister was Germaine of Foix, Queen consort of Aragon as the second wife of Ferdinand II. His paternal grandparents were Gaston IV of Foix-Grailly and Queen regnant Eleanor of Navarre. His maternal grandparents were Charles, Duke of Orléans and Marie of Cleves. His only maternal uncle was Louis XII of France.
For more update, please follow @GeoffreyMarchal on Twitter.

description.text:
I live in a part of the world where air conditioning isn't really necessary, and during the brief part of the year where it gets uncomfortably warm inside, we usually just put a fan in the window. From time to time, though, I'd come home to discover that a surprise gust of wind had blown the fan onto my bedroom floor or sucked it out onto the roof. Luckily this is a problem easily solved with just a little 3D printing.

Here you'll find a clip you can print one or two of (I'm using two) for holding your fan upright under your window. You may need to make minor modifications if your box fan or window have a different thickness (this assumes 104mm and 36mm, respectively).

description.text:
Customizable Edgy Fidget Star (pick-a-weight)

update 2017-09-30
Allow for ISO 4032 M10 (16mm) and M12 (18mm) hex nuts along with the old DIN 934 M10 (17mm) and M12 (19mm).

Easy to Customize

  • type of edge: beveled, rounded (filleted), or plain (edge width = 0)
  • type of weight: 5/16, 3/8, M8, M10 hex nut, 5/16, 3/8, 1/2, 5/8 loose ball bearing
  • number of points
  • edge width (in mm)
  • length of point (yAspect)

Disclaimer:

I'm not responsible for any injuries to you or others caused by the misuse of this potentially pointy object

Notes:

  • nuts larger than 5/16" or M8 will protrude
  • I like using vise grips to install hardware
  • if a nut is loose in a PLA frame, dip nut in frame into hot water to shrink frame around nut
  • See my collection of all of my fidget spinner designs

description.text:
This is a travel controller for the Nintendo Switch. The Joycons just friction fit into the slots on the sides and it's good to go! Very comfortable to use and helps with the reach from the right thumbstick to the ABXY buttons.

Full article on the project is here and you can follow along with my 3D printing shenanigans at https://www.saltfabs.com

E: May 7th 2017; fixed some naked edges in the original model

Update: February 12th, 2018: Uploaded a split version of the controller to eliminate the need for supports. title: Super-Secret High-Security Key
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
If you tried to make my Safety "Keyed" Light Switch Cover with the Front Slit, you probably said to yourself: "Hey! This guy designed this impossible to circumvent security device, and he didn't provide a key!" Cry no more. This Super-Secret High-Security Key will not only make you the envy of all your friends (and enemies) but it will also allow you to easily turn your light switches on and - yes - off again, without having to resort to other, more inferior tools. 3D print the best, or, better yet, remix this bad-boy, and make a better one!

Here's the original light switch cover: Safety "Keyed" Light Switch - Front Slit

http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2295821

If you have any ideas or modifications, please feel free to share them in the comments below!

FlashForge

Creator Pro

No

No

Medium

30%

Notes:

It prints, unless you try to print it on-end, and then I would laugh. But please, do share your alternatively-angled print! Personally, I think black PLA is badass, but what do I know?
I had to ream the hole a little on the end with a reamer. A few filament spiders made the hole its home.

Fusion 360 and Simplify3D

I measured a light-switch, and estimated measurements with a set of digital calipers. I guesstimated down to the nearest 1 mm.

Designed in Fusion 360, and sent it directly over to Simplify3D.

description.text:
I created this to protect the corners on my Jawbone Big Jambox.  As a side result, the elevated speakers seems to provide a little more bass possibly due to bouncing off of the surface??  
There are two versions included in this Thing.  The first model is for just the bottom feet.  The second model is for protection for the entire top, bottom and sides of the Jambox.  Just print two of each version you would like to use.  
Would probably look really interesting to mix and match colors with your Jambox color and filament.  As always, please remix and share ideas of how to improve my models.  
Thanks for looking!!!

Created these designs in Sketchup and printed on my 3D Systems Cube Gen 2 with a raft.  The raft is difficult to remove on my printers projects, so hopefully your printer produces a much smoother side than mine is showing.  
No support structure is necessary if you lay the model down flat.

The models were created in Moray for Windows ( http://www.stmuc.com/moray/medown.html ). The attached zipfile contains the plugin I wrote to export primitives from Moray directly to OpenSCAD (see readme in zipfile for instructions). This impeller housing was designed to work with a 35.5 mm diameter motor having a 4 mm diameter shaft, and mounting holes about 25.4 mm apart (M3). It was built around a scaled version of the impeller here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:34563/#comments. The motor I used came out of a cheap 18 V electric drill.

.mdl files were created in Moray For Windows ( http://www.stmuc.com/moray/medown.html ). The zipfile contains the export plugin to OpenSCAD which was used to compile STL files from the Moray scenegraph. Note - Moray exports primitives, not meshes. Excellent for doing CSG :D

Our shower head holder broke a couple of days ago and as you can't buy those things on their own, I decided to design and print one instead of buying a whole new shower set.

I probably went OTT printing it at 100% infill but I thought as it gets used regularly it'd probably be best to make it as strong as possible.

The cone shaped hole where the shower head slides in to is 24mm dia at the top and 22,, dia at the bottom, our shower head fits in there perfectly.

Hope it'll be useful to some one out there.

Its another fidget spinner using 22mm Bearings and 9/16" nuts for weight

Added a cap to lock in the nuts. It assumes that you are using a 9/16 - 12 nut

I needed to label a stack of DVD's, and didn't want to pay for a label applicator, so I decided to roll my own.

Print the body and the plug separately, then use a 30mm pen spring with a little superglue to put it all together.

EDIT: After using this for a while, I found that the plug is a little more wobbly than I'd like, and the label "finger" slots are a little too narrow. If I printed this again, I'd probably put vertical guide grooves in the body with tongues on the plug to keep it going up and down and not wobbling. That would required some sort of twist/lock mechanism from the top, or that the bottom plate be removable to allow insertion of the spring. I included the source STEP file, so you should be able to at least use this as a starting point.

title: ImpulseRC Helix ZX5 Extra Durable Fairing

description.text:
Started from a blank model, and a trace of the Helix arms, et voila! A durable Helix fairing with tons of room for ESCs. I'll update this more later, but max ESC height is 20mm!! Length is 36mm. Thickness is roughly 1.8mm all around, so in PETG this means you're just about indestructible!

Prints awesome with 0.2mm layer height, 100% infill. It needs support, but I've been pleasantly surprised with how little it actually needs.

I plan to make a couple of versions of this, so stay tuned! Currently in the works are a lightweight version, ventilated version, LED integrated version, screwless self-locating ziptie version, motor guard, and minimalist version. And I guess various permutations of those.

There's a couple flipped ones, various hole configurations. Make sure you get the right one!

Please comment if you have any suggestions/specific needs or sizes. Happy to accommodate.

The ZX6 Fairings are here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2322616

description.text:
10-5-17 added a version based on a Bike used by a German bike club
5-15-16...It's been updated again.
Front forks are curved.
Handlebars are shortened
Tire rims have 45 degree champfer
One version has a flat back to print with now support if that side is down
Original size and 125% scaled version of both models are loaded.
All new files are named 5-15... I first did this in May 2012 in Sketchup. At that time, I did not know some things I know now, one of them is how to make really round circles. Attached are several new versions and a new Sketchup version Advanced improved bike pendant has rounder hubs and wheels and a thicker seat. Balloon tire bike pendent is the advance one with round balloon tires added. I know, wrong bike frame for them. Balloon Tire bike pendent flat sided is the above but with tires trimmed so you can print it lying flat like the original. I uploaded a 200 % version one with supports and one without.
I uploaded a 100% version of the Balloon tire with tree supports. These treelike supports work well and were generated in the latest version of Meshmixer For those of you who do big organized bike rides with friends I uploaded a couple of versions with interlocked bikes for your rest stops. I also added a version I quickly did by eye in DesignSpark. I wanted to fool around with rounding edges. I need to give it a print. I think it could print flat without support.

This printed very quickly without a raft, it is small enough to fit on a keychain. You could use it with the key for a bike rack or bike lock. I centered it on the platform in Replicator G and just used the standard settings without a raft. When I printed it, the seat disappeared. It is so small, though, that that did not make a difference to me. UPDATE:
All models can be scaled to meet your needs.
Advanced improved bike...can print flat as can the Balloon Tire bike pendent flat.
The Balloon tire needs to be printed vertically or at an angle with support. Since the tires are wider than the frame.

author: viva3dprt

title: Magnetic Spool Holder Bracket for Creality CR-10

description.text:
This is a simple bearing based spool holder that attaches to the top of the Creality CR-10 control box for smoother filament feeding and adjustable for various size spools. Designed to use 625ZZ bearings and M5x10mm button cap screws and washers. Print 2 of these brackets and use a washer between the bearing and printed part to avoid any type of binding of the bearing. The screw cap on the inside does not need a washer.

Designed for three 6mm diameter 6mm long neodymium magnets press fit into bracket to hold in place on top of control box. Adjust space between each bracket to width of desired spool. I've included SkethUp source file in case you want to adjust the diameter of the holes for different size/types of magnets.

I find routing the filament from underneath the spool to the printer works well in trapping the filament on the spool and avoiding unwinding on retractions for fuller spools.

description.text:
My designs are powered by tips, if you use them, like them, and want to see more, tip me here; http://paypal.me/jametheth

After snapping my stock frame, and trying a few replacement 90~105 mm frames here on Thingiverse, I didn't really find one that I was happy with all around.

In the end I decided to go ahead and design my own ultimate "SuperStock" 3d printed QX95 frame, based on the stock design.

This was designed around the original QX95 board, though should fit most of Eachines small F3EVO boards. (QX90 etc)

I have gone through a few revisions, lots of flights crashes and breaks, and I am sure there will be more, but at the moment this thing is my new favorite "stock style" setup for the qx95 guts.

It is about half the weight of the stock frame (approximately 4.4 G), same exact dimensions/geometry as the stock frame, uses the stock rubber grommets (provide great vibration dampening), cam mounts in the same way as stock, hooks for rubber band battery mount.

Printed in PETG it is generally rigid, but has just the right amount of flex to keep it from breaking in most crashes.

Between this frame, removing the led strip, and swapping the cam/vtx out with a lighter unit, I have shaved off over 5 grams from the stock all up weight with stock battery.

I recommend mounting your flight controller and camera using a double strip of thick double sided sticky tape at the front and the back, same with camera.

title: Toy spring
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: Can it be printed successfully? Sure! Coils touche only at the edge of each level so it's easy to separate them.

Printer:

mElephant

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

layer 0.2 mm

Infill:

100%

Notes:

You can use touching-buildplate support (and raft) to prevent model displacement during printing.
Using the back of a box cutter to separate coils is recommended.

It's actually inspired by Customizable Slinky. I put a helix_extrude module in my library. This thing is an example of application. The code is easy if you use the module.

include <circle_path.scad>;
include <helix.scad>;

include <rotate_p.scad>;
include <cross_sections.scad>;
include <polysections.scad>;

include <helix_extrude.scad>;

spring_radius = 25;
spring_levels = 30;
spring_sides = 48;
line_thickness = 2.5; 

module toy_spring(radius, levels, sides, line_thickness) {
    $fn = 4;
    shape_pts = concat(
        circle_path(radius = line_thickness / 2)
    );

    helix_extrude(shape_pts, 
        radius = radius, 
        levels = levels, 
        level_dist = line_thickness,
        $fn = sides
    );
}

toy_spring(
    spring_radius, 
    spring_levels, 
    spring_sides, 
    line_thickness
);

• OpenSCAD Documentation - Traditional Chinese
  • OpenSCAD Documentation - English

remixed_from.title: FlashForge Creator Pro front dual fan duct

title: Flashforge Creator Pro / Dreamer Dual two nozzle blower for Raffle aluminium Y carriage

description.text:
After upgrading my Flashforge Creator Pro with an aluminium carriage from Raffle (www.raffle.ch) I noticed that I could not fit the original dual nozzle fan mount from DrLex any more, as the aluminium Y carriage needed a clearing of approx. 18.5mm

V4 - The air flow seems to be okay now, i.e. when printing at 230° and switching the part cooling fan on the nozzle temperature does not change compared to printing with part cooling fan switched off. Also added 0.5mm for the aluminium carriage spacer, as the V3 print broke apart when installing it in the printer.

I converted the original STL from DrLex with DesignSpark Mechanical into SAT format, which I could import into Onshape. In Onshape I could rather easily start of with the original design and change the blower part to allow for more space for the changed Y carriage.
Whoever is interested in the Onshape source - see here:
https://cad.onshape.com/documents/440d66e042069a7883b6d121/w/03ea2a2d3a512403840a624c/e/690af92998ad22093ec460ab

print_settings.Notes:: Print two of the Slider files. Print one of everything else. On the bottom piece, fins print in the air (so correct orientation if needed)

description.text:
This is my most recent version of my Pelican rocket series. This design comes with multiple new features:

Standing design
Redesigned nose
Engine holder
More Parachute room
Redesigned body
Easy way to attach parts

Please note that additional sanding may need to be done to the connecting pieces and engine holder!!!

Printer Brand:

PowerSpec

Printer:

Ultra 3D

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Resolution:

.05mm-.2mm

Infill:

10%-30%

Notes:

Print two of the Slider files. Print one of everything else. On the bottom piece, fins print in the air (so correct orientation if needed)

Step 1
Print our model rocket in PLA filament with provided print settings.

Step 2
Assemble rocket by fitting bottom and middle together. Then slip over the connecter piece and use a heat gun or hairdryer to shrink it. This should make a tight fitting bond between the two parts.

Step 3
Cut rubber band so that it is one long string. Glue one end of band to inside of the middle section of the rocket where the nose is inserted. Glue other end to the bottom of the nose.

Step 4
Tie strings of parachute in middle of rubber band.

Step 5
Insert band and parachute into the middle section with tissue paper to block the parachute from fire.

Step 6
Glue on two slider pieces in a straight line. One will be on the bottom piece and the other on the middle piece.

Step 7
Insert model rocket engine, igniter, and ignitor holder to the bottom of the rocket. Fit in the nozzle and slide the rocket into a launch pad rod. Attach the electric ignitor leads, push the button, and blast off!!!

title: RMRC 8" Monitor All-in-One Ground Station with Goggle output

description.text:
An all-in-one ground station designed around the RMRC 8" monitor. Provides space for the very popular FR632 diversity RX. It also features power and video out for goggles. If you want to use an alternate video source such as a 1.2/2.4 video receiver, the goggle video out can double as a video in. I have also added a video source selector switch to the bottom which allows you to choose between "live video" and DVR video. The battery holder is designed to hold batteries from 3300mah 3s and smaller. Depending on demand, I can make a video showing the wiring.

Here's a list of what I'm using. Mostly everything comes from Banggood and RMRC.

8" monitor

The 4 inch parts trays can often be had free with any purchase if you can find the appropriate coupon, meaning you can setup the 2 tray mount for the cost of a couple of snap off razors (like 59 cents each).

The smallest tray holds one 4 inch parts tray from Harbor Freight.
The second tray holds two of the same parts tray.
https://www.harborfreight.com/4-inch-magnetic-parts-tray-90566.html

The third tray holds the larger 9.5 inch magnetic parts tray from Harbor Freight.
https://www.harborfreight.com/9-1-2-half-inch-magnetic-parts-tray-with-hood-97801.html
This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/7ItTRRDGZdp

Hey there,

I remixed the great Ciclop design in a cost and time saving version for those who print it by themselves.

The key improvements are:

  • no need for bearing, only Ø6 mm ball spheres. This is taken from http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1454048
  • no need for M8 rods
  • decreased the amount of PLA needed for the camera and motor support.
  • modified camera and motor support feet to cope with wood 8mm rods.
  • the shaft needs a header 4mm (6mm long) that you screw with a key though the hole I added to the motor support

Note that the shaft and round support are now one piece and it is 5mm lower than original one, but this has not impact on the scans from my experience. In order to save material, I reduced the diameter to 10cm instead of 20cm. One can then put a 20cm disc above if needed.

Printed in PLA, 200C/55C on Alunar M508

This is a tower I made with a ton of blocks.
I tried to make it twice as tall, but I think the tinker cad server couldn't handle doing that because it crashed my session. Oh well, enjoy my art piece.

Made a perch for my bird to hang out with me instead of jumping all around my desk. Now he has a spot he can sit and be comfortable. Base is wide enough for safety. I did with no infill on the base, paused the print and added sand. Then continued and let the print close up. The top, I printed with 50% infill. You may have to do a light sanding on the bottom for the 2 to combine, or you can print it all in one shot. Anyway, enjoy your time with your bird!

Built a few of the common 608 bearing spinners with the caps. There are a few other penny spinners out there, including one with a 3d printed bearing.. But mine only requires you to press in 15 pennies. No installation of a bearing, no glue needed for the pennies. Use a socket, and hammer in 5 pennies in each pocket. The bearing in the center is more of a bushing, but if you spray some WD-40 it spins pretty decently for a plastic bushing.

Print this with no support, it is self supporting.

comments.text: Now that it's broken in, with a good spin with another hand, I can get it to spin for about 10-15 seconds.. I think because of the needed gap, it doesn't run completely balanced but still impressive for what it is.

This is a "speed washer", most commonly used on the outside surface of skateboard bearings (one on each side). The washer provides solid contact with the bearing inner race, keeping the covers from rubbing on a truck or nut -- improving speed.

They're very thin and small, to minimally impact spacing.

These also work really well for fidget spinners -- if your favorite caps don't already have a small spacer built-in. Some do, some don't.

This is a tiny part; bed adhesion will be important. I use PLA on glass, with some glue stick (PVA).
Yes, it's finally here. This will take about 21 hours to print and its 209x191x24mm big. Don't you dare scale it down.

title: Wanhao D6 - Monoprice Ultimate Logitech C270 Camera Mount

description.text:
Uploaded a v2 version which is extended closer to center of build area but a couple cm farther back from the print area. This improves the the depth of view in focus. Also better fit onto the printer frame and easier to remove..

Just a quick lightweight and mostly easy to move mount for the Logitech C270 camera on the Wanhao Duplicator 6 aka Monoprice Ultimate. Remixed parts of http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1199083 and http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1663067.

Fits snug and clear of build area with left-hand 40mm fan cooler and probably any other popular cooler mod. Print a focus ring for the C270 to adjust focus to near center of your build area.

M2 screw holds camera tight with no nut required. Mount about level with your nozzle, point camera downwards a little and you'll always have a view of nozzle while printing as the bed lowers.

Printer:

Monoprice Maker Ultimate

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.22

Infill:

High

Notes:

A little bit of support recommended for the camera screw mount area which protrudes a few mm above the print bed.

comments.text: Neat, can you make an interior mount too? I have an enclosure that isn't exactly transparent (it's cardboard panels from the box the printer came in).
comments.author: kritter

comments.text: Not enough clearance with the C270 camera on the inside. At least not with modified blower hot end coolers. Would need someone with stock cooling or perhaps the dual fan cooling to measure clearance. Would be a tight fit either way and the depth of field for focus for this camera would shrink even further if mounted inside. I would look for a much smaller camera for this purpose.

Pat made the original drone tools holder. Considering I had the same Dynamite Hex Driver Set it seemed a great starting point for me.

I made two changes:
